title: 106_hr699
content: The "Building Opportunities Bonus Act" provides a bonus to build real opportunities for poor families. The Building Opportunities Bonus Act amends Section 403(a) of the Social Security Act to provide grants to high performing States based on their scores from the previous fiscal year. The Building Opportunities Bonus Act limits the amount payable to a State to 5 percent of the State family assistance grant for a bonus year. The funds are to be used to address specific criteria for measuring State performance in operating the State program funded under this part. The Building Opportunities Bonus Act limits State assistance to 5% of the family grant for a bonus year. States must ensure adequate, safe, accessible, and quality child care slots, help place children in suitable care, fill available slots, and improve provider training and pay. The curr_chunk discusses increasing access to safe and quality child care by providing subsidies to families earning up to 85% of the State's median income and collaborating with child care experts. The curr_chunk focuses on collaborating with State domestic violence coalitions to address child care needs of families affected by domestic violence and ensuring recipients of assistance are provided education and training for sustainable employment opportunities. The curr_chunk emphasizes providing career development assistance, job readiness training, counseling services, and employability assessments to women in welfare-to-work programs. It also mentions utilizing resources under title I of the Workforce. The curr_chunk highlights State efforts under the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 to support education, training, placement, retention, and career development. It also mentions collaboration with State domestic violence coalitions to address domestic violence as a barrier to women's employment. The curr_chunk focuses on programs addressing domestic violence as a barrier to women's work and education, including demonstration projects, placing advocates in welfare offices, and providing employment and support services for victims. It also emphasizes collaboration with State domestic violence coalitions. The curr_chunk emphasizes collaboration with State domestic violence coalitions for training on domestic violence in various programs funded under this part. The curr_chunk focuses on implementing strategies and programs to support victims of domestic violence in the workplace, conducting outreach to employers, and public education on domestic violence. The curr_chunk outlines the criteria for assigning scores to eligible States for bonus grants, with specific performance thresholds to ensure a total grant amount of $1,000,000,000 for all bonus years. Definitions for the bonus grant program include "bonus year" referring to fiscal years 2001-2005, "child care" encompassing various care programs for children up to age 14, and "child with special needs" defined within the program. The term 'child with special needs' is defined as a child with a disability under the Individuals With Disabilities Education Act. 'Domestic violence' is defined as being battered or subjected to extreme cruelty. A 'high performance State' is an eligible State with a high score in the preceding fiscal year for the bonus grant program. The term 'sustainable wage' refers to a wage that is 185 percent above the poverty line, considering various employment-related costs. 'Nontraditional employment' includes occupations or fields of work outside the norm. The term 'nontraditional employment' refers to occupations or fields where one gender comprises less than 25 percent of the workforce. Authorization of appropriations totaling $1,000,000,000 is provided for grants in fiscal years 2001 through 2005.
